importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Ali Danial Hemani was indicted in 2023 on a charge related to the federal guns-and-drugs law after marijuana and cocaine were found at his home.
The Supreme Court agreed to review the federal law banning drug users from possessing guns in October 2025.
Hunter Biden was convicted in 2024 under the same federal law, later pardoned by President Joe Biden.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The Supreme Court is expected to issue a decision on the Hemani case by the end of June 2025.

keyTakeAways: The Supreme Court agreed to review whether the federal law banning certain drug users from possessing guns violates the Second Amendment.
The case centers on Ali Danial Hemani, a dual citizen of the United States and Pakistan, who was charged with violating the law after marijuana and cocaine were found at his home.
The Trump administration argued that habitual drug users with firearms pose a significant risk to public safety, especially during impaired encounters with law enforcement.
A federal district court dismissed the charge, citing the 2022 Supreme Court decision that requires gun prohibitions to have historical roots.
The 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled that the law cannot target habitual drug users, stating such prohibitions must be historically grounded.
The Trump administration appealed that decision, asserting that the law is necessary to prevent armed threats in society.
Hemani's legal team challenged the historical justification of the law, noting that nearly half of U.S. states have legalized recreational marijuana.
The case is part of a broader trend of Supreme Court scrutiny of gun regulations, with a related case involving state-level gun carrying restrictions on private property.
Hunter Biden was previously convicted under the same law and later pardoned by President Joe Biden.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The U.S. Supreme Court has agreed to review a federal law that bans certain drug users from possessing firearms, with the case centered on Ali Danial Hemani, a dual U.S.-Pakistan citizen who was indicted in 2023 after marijuana and cocaine were found at his home. The Trump administration defended the law, arguing that habitual drug users pose a danger to public safety, especially when impaired. However, lower courts have previously ruled that such prohibitions must have historical roots, and the 5th Circuit Court of Appeals specifically rejected targeting habitual users. Hemani and others argue that the historical justification for the law is weak, especially given that nearly half of U.S. states now allow recreational marijuana. The case is also notable for its political dimension, including the prior conviction and pardon of Hunter Biden, the son of President Joe Biden, under the same law. The Supreme Court is expected to issue a decision by the end of June 2025, and the ruling could have significant implications for gun rights and drug policy across the United States.
title: Justices Agree to Review Federal Law Banning Drug Users from Possessing Guns
